questions.question: A student with ADHD requires specialized instruction and related services that are not available in the general education curriculum. Under which legislative framework would they most likely receive an Individualized Education Program (IEP)?
options: Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act
The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Title III
The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA)
The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)
questions.explanation: IDEA is the federal law that provides for specialized instruction and IEPs for students who meet specific disability criteria, whereas Section 504 provides broader civil rights protections against discrimination.

questions.question: Under HIPAA's 'Minimum Necessary Rule,' what is the practitioner's primary obligation when sharing Protected Health Information (PHI)?
options: To provide the entire client file to any requesting healthcare provider
To disclose only the specific information required to achieve the intended purpose
To only share information via encrypted fax machines
To obtain a new written consent for every individual data point shared
questions.explanation: The 'Minimum Necessary' standard requires covered entities to take reasonable steps to limit the use or disclosure of PHI to the minimum amount necessary to accomplish the intended purpose.

questions.question: A Certified ADHD Support Specialist is asked by a client to recommend a specific dosage increase for their stimulant medication. Which action best adheres to the professional Scope of Practice?
options: Suggesting a 5mg increase based on common clinical guidelines
Providing a list of peer-reviewed studies on dosage for the client to show their doctor
Refusing to discuss medication entirely to avoid any legal risk
Directing the client to discuss all dosage adjustments with their prescribing physician
questions.explanation: Non-clinical specialists must never provide medical advice or dosage recommendations. This falls outside the scope of practice and constitutes the unlicensed practice of medicine.

questions.question: In Contract Law, what is the legal term for the 'exchange of value' that makes a service agreement between a specialist and a client legally binding?
options: Mutual Assent
Consideration
Promissory Estoppel
Exculpatory Clause
questions.explanation: Consideration is the value (usually a fee) exchanged for services. Without consideration, a contract is generally not enforceable.

questions.question: Based on the landmark Tarasoff v. Regents of the University of California case, when does a professional's 'Duty to Warn' supersede client confidentiality?
options: When a client admits to past illegal drug use
When a client expresses vague frustration with a co-worker
When a client makes a specific, credible threat of serious physical violence against an identifiable victim
When a client's spouse requests information about the client's progress
questions.explanation: The Duty to Warn applies when there is a specific threat to an identifiable person, creating a legal obligation to protect the intended victim.

questions.question: According to the ADA, what is the 'Interactive Process' in a workplace setting?
options: A mandatory weekly meeting between all neurodivergent employees
A collaborative dialogue between employer and employee to determine effective reasonable accommodations
A formal disciplinary procedure for employees who fail to meet quotas
The process of interviewing candidates with disabilities
questions.explanation: The interactive process is the flexible, collaborative dialogue required by the ADA to identify appropriate accommodations for a disability.

questions.question: An ADHD specialist carries a 'Claims-made' professional indemnity insurance policy. If a claim is filed in 2024 for an incident that occurred in 2022, which condition must be met for the claim to be covered?
options: The specialist must have been with the same insurance company for 5 years
The policy must have been active in 2022 only
The policy must be active at the time the claim is made and have a retroactive date covering 2022
Claims-made policies do not cover past incidents under any circumstances
questions.explanation: Claims-made policies cover incidents that occur on or after a retroactive date, provided the policy is active at the time the claim is officially filed.

questions.question: A 2023 audit of compliance systems found that 62% of data breaches in small practices were caused by 'Human Error.' Which Quality Assurance measure is most effective at mitigating this risk?
options: Increasing the complexity of the firewall
Implementing mandatory, recurring staff training on data handling protocols
Deleting all digital records and moving to paper-only filing
Hiring an external lawyer to review every email sent
questions.explanation: Regular training is the primary defense against human error, ensuring staff understand and follow security protocols consistently.

questions.question: Under the GDPR, what is the 'Right to Erasure' (also known as the Right to be Forgotten)?
options: The right of the practitioner to delete records of non-paying clients
The right of a client to request the deletion of their personal data when it is no longer necessary for the original purpose
The requirement to destroy all records every 12 months
The right of the government to seize and delete clinical notes
questions.explanation: The Right to Erasure allows individuals to request that their data be deleted by a controller, subject to certain legal exceptions (like statutory record-keeping requirements).

questions.question: A client with ADHD is struggling with sensory overload in an open-plan office. Which of the following would generally NOT be considered a 'Reasonable Accommodation' under the ADA if it causes 'undue hardship'?
options: Providing noise-canceling headphones
Allowing the use of a white noise machine
Constructing a new, soundproof private wing of the building for a single employee
Relocating the employee's desk to a quieter corner
questions.explanation: An accommodation is not 'reasonable' if it requires significant difficulty or expense (undue hardship). Building a new wing is typically considered an undue hardship compared to simpler adjustments.
